--- Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...> wrote:
> 
> > > This is very interesting experimental design. 
> Did
> > > you also consider
> > > inputting the start sequence with indices (e.g.
> M
> > > inputs for data and N
> > > inputs for "address" -- probably just setting
> one
> > > address-line high, not
> > > full binary numbers) and then ask for the data
> back
> > > by repeating the
> > > address sequence.
> >
> >No.  That would be a different problem, also worth
> >doing.  I'm modeling phone dialing; you hear a
> phone
> >number, 7 sounds in sequence, then after only a
> very
> >short delay you repeat it back in the same
> sequence,
> >either by speaking it or dialing it.
> 
> I'm not so sure about it being a different problem. 
> E.g. for short 
> sequences at least, I can answer questions like
> "what digit was third" or 
> "what came after the seven" as easily as I can
> repeat the sequence 
> back.  And I would not assume that this is three
> separate mechanisms acting 
> on the same data.
> 
> e.g. to go back to a point discussed a while back,
> breaking a problem into 
> small pieces can make it harder.  So, for example, a
> net which can answer 
> "what came after the seven" might make a necessary
> stepping-stone on the 
> way to one which can recall the whole sequence.

It would be possible to evolve a net that could recall
patterns given an index rather than sequentially.  It
is also possible, that evolving such a network for
very small data sets, and then growing it, might work
very well.  One would have to try it.

<snip>
> I'm very interested in any ideas or experiments for
> how brains are able to 
> apply different concepts together like this.  It's
> just the same as the 
> discussion we had about whether 4play could exploit
> symmetry or not and 
> whether a human brain can learn board-symmetry from
> checkers and apply it 
> to chess.
> 
> > > >This is very similar to what is done by my
> 4Play
> > > >program, except 4Play did more complex logic
> than
> > > just
> > > >repeating memorize values.
> > >
> > > I'd say this was asking for a more complex net,
> > > however...
> >
> >Which do you think is more complex?
> 
> The phone numbers are more complex.  Assuming I
> remember 4play correctly, 
> it only had to recall the positions of 4 symbols
> amongst 4 
> places.  Treating that naively, it's only 8 bits of
> data.  A seven-digit 
> phone number is 28 bits of data, even without
> questions of remembering the 
> "cursor" position...

The phone number has more data, but the 4Play problem
has more complex processing to apply to the data. 

m
